title: Configure load balancers for OO
content:
Configure external ALB for OO 

You can access OO from outside the Kubernetes cluster using an AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB).

The diagram below depicts how to separate Service Management and OO access through the two ALBs, while the communication between Service Management and OO happens through the integration ALB.

F
  1. The Integration ALB must be internal, you can access it only from the VPC.
  2. The two 'external' ALBs used for accessing Service Management and OO can be either internal or internet-facing, based on your preference. 
    • The term 'external' here is to emphasize that these ALBs are routing only the traffic that comes from outside the Kubernetes cluster.  

Prerequisites

Before creating and configuring an ALB:

  • Assign an FQDN for the OO Load Balancer. For example, see AWS route 53 services if you don't have one.
    • The FQDN is a subdomain of the Service Management FQDN.
    • For example, if Service Management is FQDN is smax.example.com, then OO FQDN is oo.smax.example.com.

Use a certificate for the ALB, which you can generate or import to AWS Certificates Manager. The certificate's target domain name (CN name) is the FQDN you will bind with the ALB in a later step.

You can prepare a certificate for this Load Balancer using one of the following methods:

Request a certificate

If you want to request a new certificate, follow these steps:

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console in your target region.
  2. Navigate to All services > Security, Identity, & Compliance > Certificate Manager.
  3. If the firstrun page displays, click Get Started.
  4. Click Request a certificate.
  5. Select Request a public certificate and click Next.
  6. Specify your target domain name. Use an asterisk (*) to request a wildcard certificate to protect several sites in the same domain. For example, *.testoo-conteinarized.org.
  7. Select DNS validation or Email validation according to your permission.
  8. Click Request.
  9. Finish the certificate validation based on the method you just selected. For more information, see DNS validation.

Import a certificate

If you want to use a custom certificate, follow these steps:

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console in your target region.
  2. Navigate to All services > Security, Identity, & Compliance > Certificate Manager.
  3. If the firstrun page displays, click Get Started.
  4. Click Import a certificate.
  5. For Certificate body, paste the PEM encoded certificate to import.
  6. For Certificate private key, paste the PEM encoded, unencrypted private key that matches the certificate's public key.
    Currently, services integrated with AWS Certificate Manager support only the RSA_1024 and RSA_2048 algorithms.
  7. (Optional) For Certificate chain, paste the PEM encoded certificate chain.
  8. Click Next > Review and import > Import.

Create an Ingress for OO

You need to create an Ingress for OO with port 443:

  1. On the bastion node, save the content below as oo-ingress.yaml: 
    apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  name: "oo-ingress"
  namespace: "<OO_namespace>"
  annotations:
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/scheme: <ALB_scheme>
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/group.name: <ALB_name>
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/listen-ports: '[{"HTTPS": 443}]'
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/backend-protocol: HTTPS
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/healthcheck-protocol: HTTPS
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/healthcheck-port: traffic-port
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/healthcheck-path: /healthz
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/success-codes: 200-399
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/target-type: instance
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/load-balancer-attributes: idle_timeout.timeout_seconds=180
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/certificate-arn: <ALB_cert_arn>
  labels:
    app: oo-ingress
spec:
  ingressClassName: alb
  tls:
  - hosts:
    - <external_access_host>
  rules:
    - host:
      http:
        paths:
          - backend:
              service:
                name: "<oo-nginx-controller-svc>"
                port:
                  number: 443
            path: /*
            pathType: ImplementationSpecific

    Replace the following with the actual values:

    <OO_namespace>: The actual namespace where you installed OO. For example, oo.
    <ALB_scheme>: Possible values: internet-facing or internal. According to your requirement, set the ALB scheme to:
    internet-facing if you want access OO from the internet, with filtering defined through the security group associated with the load balancer.
    internal if you want to access OO only from within the VPC. 
    <ALB_name>: Specify a name for this ALB. For example: oo-ext-alb. The name must consist of lowercase alphanumeric characters, '-', or '.', and must start and end with an alphanumeric character.
    <ALB_cert_arn>: The Amazon resource name of the certificate prepared for this Load Balancer. For example, arn:aws:acm:region:123456789012:certificate/12345678-1234-1234-1234-123456789012. For more information, see the section "Prerequisites".
    <external_access_host>: The FQDN you assigned for this Load Balancer. For example, oo.smax.example.com.
    <oo-nginx-controller-svc>: The Kubernetes service name of OO deployed Nginx ingress controller. You can obtain it by running the following command on the bastion host: 
    kubectl get svc -n <oo_namespace> | grep -i itom-ingress | awk '{print$1}'
  2. Run the following command to apply the saved YAML file: 
    kubectl create -f oo-ingress.yaml

Bind an FQDN with OO ALB

After you create and configure the ALB for OO, bind the FQDN that you assigned for OO with this ALB. To do so, see Bind FQDN with ALB.

Configure integration ALB

To enable Service Management and OO Containerized to work together in AWS, configure an internal ALB between the Ingress service of Service Management and the Ingress service of OO. 

The diagram below depicts how the integration ALB sets up the connection between Service Management and OO:

Listener port number Listener port description
2443 All traffic on this port is routed towards the SMA components. 
4443 All traffic on this port is routed towards the OO components. 

Prerequisites

Before creating and configuring an integration ALB:

  • Assign an FQDN for the integration Load Balancer. For example, using the AWS route 53 services.
  • Have AWS Load Balancer Controller add-on installed in your EKS cluster. For more information, see Installing the AWS Load Balancer Controller add-on.

Use a certificate for the ALB, which you can generate or import to AWS Certificates Manager. The target domain name (CN name) of the certificate is the full name of the FQDN you will bind with the ALB in a later step.

You can prepare a certificate for this Load Balancer using one of the following methods:

Request a certificate

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console in your target region.
  2. Navigate to Services > Certificate Manager.
  3. Click Request a certificate.
  4. Select Request a public certificate and click Request a certificate.
  5. Specify your target domain name. You can use an asterisk (*) to request a wildcard certificate to protect several sites in the same domain. For example, *.testsma-ng.org.
  6. Click Next.
  7. Select DNS validation or Email validation according to your permission.
  8. Click Review and then click Confirm and request.
  9. Click Continue.
  10. Finish the certificate validation based on the method you just selected. For more information, see DNS validation.

Import a certificate

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console in your target region.
  2. Navigate to Services > Certificate Manager.
  3. Click Import a certificate.
  4. For Certificate body, paste the PEM encoded certificate.
  5. For Certificate private key, paste the PEM encoded, unencrypted private key that matches the certificate's public key. 
    Important: Currently, services integrated with AWS Certificate Manager support only the RSA_1024 and RSA_2048 algorithms.
  6. (Optional) For Certificate chain, paste the PEM encoded certificate chain.
  7. Click Next > Review and import > Import.

Create an Ingress for integration between OO and Service Management

Use the AWS ALB to serve end users to access the suite from web browsers. You need to create an ALB for integration and add a listener to the ALB for OO and Service Management respectively during the creation.

Step 1: Create an Ingress for OO integration

To create an Ingress for OO integration, follow these steps:

  1. Save the content below as oo-internal-ingress.yaml: 
    apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  name: "oo-internal-ingress"
  namespace: <oo_namespace>
  annotations:
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/scheme: internal
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/group.name: <integration_alb_name>
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/listen-ports: '[{"HTTPS": 4443}]'
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/backend-protocol: HTTPS
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/healthcheck-protocol: HTTPS
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/healthcheck-port: traffic-port
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/healthcheck-path: /healtz
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/success-codes: 200-399
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/target-type: instance
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/load-balancer-attributes: idle_timeout.timeout_seconds=180
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/certificate-arn: <certificate_arn>
  labels:
    app: oo-internal-ingress
spec:
  ingressClassName: alb
  tls:
  - hosts:
    - <integration_LB_host>
  rules:
    - host:
      http:
        paths:
          - backend:
              service:
                name: <oo-nginx-controller-svc>
                port:
                  number: 443
            path: /*
            pathType: ImplementationSpecific

    Replace the following with the actual values:
    <OO_namespace>: The actual namespace where you installed OO. For example, oo.
    <integration_alb_name>: Specify a name for this ALB. For example: oo-int-alb. The name must consist of lowercase alphanumeric characters, '-', or '.', and must start and end with an alphanumeric character.
    <certificate_arn>: The Amazon resource name of the certificate prepared for this Load Balancer. For example, arn:aws:acm:region:123456789012:certificate/12345678-1234-1234-1234-123456789012. For more information, see the section "Prerequisites".
    <integration_LB_host>: The FQDN you assigned for this Load Balancer. For example, oo.smax.example.com.
    <oo-nginx-controller-svc>: The Kubernetes service name of OO deployed Nginx ingress controller. You can obtain it by running the following command on the bastion host:

    kubectl get svc -n <oo_namespace> | grep -i itom-ingress | awk '{print$1}'
  2. Run the following command to apply the saved YAML file: 
    kubectl create -f /path/to/oo-internal-ingress.yaml

Step 2: Create an Ingress for Service Management integration

To create an Ingress for Service Management integration, follow these steps:

  1. Save the content below as smax-integration-ingress.yaml: 
    apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  name: "sma-ingress"
  namespace: <itsma_namespace>
  annotations:
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/group.name: <integration_alb_name>
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/listen-ports: '[{"HTTPS": 2443}]'
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/backend-protocol: HTTPS
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/healthcheck-protocol: HTTPS
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/healthcheck-port: traffic-port
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/healthcheck-path: /healthz
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/success-codes: 200-399
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/target-type: instance
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/load-balancer-attributes: idle_timeout.timeout_seconds=180
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/certificate-arn: <certificate_arn>
  labels:
    app: sma-integration-ingress
spec:
  ingressClassName: alb
  tls:
  - hosts:
    - <integration_LB_host>
  rules:
    - host: 
      http:
        paths:
          - backend:
              service: 
                name: "itom-ingress-controller-svc"
                port: 
                  number: 443
            path: /*
            pathType: ImplementationSpecific

    Replace the following with the actual values:

    <itsma_namespace>: The namespace of the Service Management deployment. For example, itsma.
    <integration_alb_name>: Use the name you specified in oo-integration-ingress.yaml.
    <certificate_arn>: Use the ARN you specified in oo-integration-ingress.yaml.
    <integration_LB_host>: The FQDN you assigned for this Load Balancer. For example, int.smax.example.com. It's the same host you provided in oo-integration-ingress.yaml.
    <oo-nginx-controller-svc>: The Kubernetes service name of OO deployed Nginx ingress controller. You can obtain it by running the following command on the bastion host: 
    kubectl get svc -n <oo_namespace> | grep -i itom-ingress | awk '{print$1}'
  2. Run the following command to apply the saved YAML file: 
    kubectl create -f smax-integration-ingress.yaml

Bind an FQDN with the integration ALB

After you create and configure the integration ALB, you need to bind an FQDN with this ALB. See Bind FQDN with ALB. 

Update OO deployment

After creating ALBs, update the OO deployment with the certificate(s) used for the ALBs. 

Copy the certificates on the Bastion host, and run the following commands in the Bastion host to update the OO installation:

  1. Get the name of the OO Helm installation. 
    [user@ip-10-0-0-1 ~]# helm list -n oo-helm
NAME            NAMESPACE       REVISION        UPDATED                                 STATUS          CHART                   APP VERSION
oo              oo-helm         18              2024-11-05 13:15:20.156866707 +0000 UTC deployed        oo-1.x.x+25.x.x         25.2
[root@ip-10-0-0-1 ~]#
  2. Reconfigure OO installation. 
    helm upgrade oo -n oo-helm --reuse-values --set-file "caCertificates.oo_lb\.crt"=/path/to/oo_external_load_balancer_certificate.crt --set-file "caCertificates.integration_lb\.crt"=/path/to/integration_load_balancer_certificate.crt

    This command takes about 2 minutes to complete.
